book_level.description: Upper elementary level - imaginative fantasy with transformation magic, clear villain motivations, and adventure elements

questions.question: Where is Mount Munch located?

options.B: On the east edge of the Land of Oz, in the Munchkin Country

questions.explanation: Mount Munch is located 'on the east edge of the Land of Oz, in the Munchkin country.'

questions.question: What shape is the top of Mount Munch?

options.B: Shaped like a saucer, broad and deep

questions.explanation: The top of Mount Munch is 'shaped like a saucer, broad and deep.'

questions.question: What do the people living on Mount Munch call themselves?
questions.explanation: The people who live on Mount Munch call themselves 'Hyups.'

questions.question: Who is Bini Aru?

options.D: A wise old Hyup who used to be a sorcerer

questions.explanation: Bini Aru is described as 'a wise old Hyup... who used to be a clever sorcerer.'

questions.question: What did Ozma decree about magic in Oz?

options.C: No one could practice magic except Glinda the Good and the Wizard of Oz
options.D: Magic was completely forbidden for everyone

questions.explanation: Ozma 'made a decree that no one should practise magic in her dominions except Glinda the Good and the Wizard of Oz.'

questions.question: What is the magic word for transformations?
questions.explanation: The magic word is 'Pyrzqxgl' which is pronounced 'Pyres Quicksicle.'

questions.question: Why was Kiki Aru noted for being cross and disagreeable?

options.A: He wanted to see the world but his father wouldn't let him leave

questions.explanation: Kiki 'was not happy because he wanted to go down the mountain and visit the big world below, and his father would not let him.'

questions.question: How did Kiki discover the magic word?

options.B: He read it in a magic book
options.D: He found it written on the underside of a loose floorboard

questions.explanation: When the board 'slipped from his hand and turned over,' Kiki 'saw something written on the underside of it' describing how to pronounce the magic word.

questions.question: What was Kiki's first transformation?
questions.explanation: Kiki said 'I want to become a big, strong bird like a hawk' for his first transformation.

questions.question: What surrounds the Land of Oz?

options.D: A deadly sandy desert with poisonous fumes

questions.explanation: Oz is surrounded by 'the Deadly Sandy Desert' with 'poisonous fumes.'

questions.question: Who is Ruggedo?

options.B: The former Gnome King who was kicked out of his kingdom

questions.explanation: Ruggedo says 'I used to be the Gnome King, but I got kicked out of my country.'

questions.question: What does Ruggedo look like?

options.A: Crooked with a fat body, thin limbs, bushy white whiskers, and pointed hair
options.B: Tall and thin with black hair
options.C: Short with red hair and a beard

questions.explanation: Ruggedo is described as crooked, with 'a fat body and thin legs and arms,' 'bushy white whiskers that came to a point,' and 'white hair that came to a point on top of his head.'

questions.question: What is Ruggedo afraid of?
questions.explanation: Ruggedo says 'I'm afraid of 'em - eggs. They are dangerous' with a shudder.

questions.question: How did Kiki get money when he had none?

options.B: He transformed into a magpie and stole a gold piece
options.D: He found it on the ground

questions.explanation: Kiki 'transformed himself into a magpie and flying through the open window, caught up one of the gold pieces in his beak.'

questions.question: What did Ruggedo carry in his bulging pockets?
questions.explanation: Ruggedo says when he left his kingdom, 'they said I could take as many precious stones as I could carry, so I had a lot of pockets made in my clothes and loaded them all up.'

questions.question: Why doesn't Oz use money?

options.D: Everyone is allowed to take what they wish without price

questions.explanation: In the Land of Oz 'they do not use money at all, every one being allowed to take what he wishes without price.'

questions.question: What is Glinda's Book of Records?

options.A: A list of all citizens in Oz
options.D: A book that magically records everything people do in Oz the instant they do it

questions.explanation: Glinda has 'a Great Book called the Book of Records, in which is magically written everything that people do in the Land of Oz, just the instant they do it.'

questions.question: What is Ozma's magic picture?

options.B: A picture in which she can see whatever she wishes to see

questions.explanation: Ozma has 'a Magic Picture in which she can see whatever she wishes to see.'

questions.question: Who is Mopsi Aru?

options.A: Kiki's mother, famous for making huckleberry pies

questions.explanation: Bini Aru 'had a wife named Mopsi Aru, who was famous for making fine huckleberry pies.'

questions.question: What is the Glass Cat made of?

options.B: Clear glass with pink brains and ruby heart

questions.explanation: The Glass Cat 'was made all of glass' with 'a mass of delicate pink balls which looked like jewels but were intended for brains' and 'a heart made of blood-red ruby.'

questions.question: Bini Aru discovered a new transformation method that was unknown to any other sorcerer. This method ---.

options.A: required many tools and magical powders
options.B: needed a wand and special potions
options.C: was the simplest thing in the world once you knew how to pronounce the mystical word
options.D: could only be performed during a full moon

questions.explanation: By Bini Aru's method, 'it was the simplest thing in the world to transform anyone into beast, bird, or fish, or anything else, and back again, once you knew how to pronounce the mystical word.'

questions.question: Bini Aru wrote down the magic word instead of just memorizing it because ---.

options.D: he wanted to preserve it in case Ozma changed the magic laws someday

questions.explanation: Bini Aru 'reflected that Ozma was a girl and sometime might change her mind and allow her subjects to practise magic' so he wanted to preserve the secret.

questions.question: Glinda's Book of Records has a loophole that the villains plan to exploit. The loophole is that the book ---.

options.A: is only read once a week
options.D: only records what people do, not what beasts or birds do

questions.explanation: Ruggedo realizes 'The book doesn't make a record of what birds do, or beasts. It only tells the doings of people. So if we fly into the country as birds, Glinda won't know anything about it.'

questions.question: Ruggedo's plan for conquering Oz involves ---.

options.C: transforming beasts into people and people into beasts

questions.explanation: Ruggedo plans to 'transform all the beasts into men and women' and 'transform all the people of Oz into beasts of various sorts and send them to live in the forests.'

questions.question: Kiki refuses to share the magic word with Ruggedo because ---.

options.C: he realizes sharing his power would be dangerous to himself
options.D: his father told him not to share it

questions.explanation: Kiki 'realized that to share his power with another would be dangerous to himself.'

questions.question: Both Kiki and Ruggedo are secretly planning to ---.

options.D: transform the other into something harmless after conquering Oz

questions.explanation: Kiki plans to 'transform the old gnome into a marble statue,' while Ruggedo plans to 'transform Kiki Aru into a bundle of faggots and burn him up.'

questions.question: The narrator makes a statement about wicked people: ---.

options.C: They are more loyal than good people
options.D: They cannot be trusted even by one another

questions.explanation: The narrator states 'This is always the way with wicked people. They cannot be trusted even by one another.'

questions.question: When Kiki transforms Ruggedo, he prevents the gnome from learning the magic word by ---.

options.B: walking away and transforming Ruggedo from a distance
options.C: writing it down instead of speaking

questions.explanation: Kiki said 'Remain here for a few minutes, and I'll soon be back' and 'walking swiftly away, he left the gnome standing in the grove' before transforming him.

questions.question: While Kiki was asleep at the inn, Ruggedo ---.

options.A: searched Kiki's room and pockets for magic tools

questions.explanation: Ruggedo 'rose softly from his couch, and went into the room of Kiki Aru... and searched everywhere for the magic tool that performed his transformations.'

questions.question: The Oz people defeated Ruggedo before by ---.

options.A: having a celebration in his honor

questions.explanation: Ruggedo says eggs are 'dreadful' and 'dangerous' to him, and the Oz people 'rolled eggs at me' to defeat him.

questions.question: Before meeting Ruggedo, Kiki visited several countries including ---.

options.B: High Land, Low Land, Merry Land, Noland, Kingdom of Ix, and Land of Ev

questions.explanation: Kiki visited 'High Land,' 'Low Land,' 'Merry Land,' 'the kingdom of Noland,' 'the Kingdom of Ix,' and 'the Land of Ev.'

questions.question: According to Ruggedo, 'abdicate' means ---.
questions.explanation: When Kiki asks what 'abdicate' means, Ruggedo says 'It means to be kicked out.'

questions.question: After leaving Mount Munch, Kiki's personality changed because ---.

options.C: having found freedom, he was no longer unhappy and thus no longer cross

questions.explanation: 'Having escaped from his home... the young man was no longer unhappy, and so he was no longer cross and disagreeable.'

questions.question: In the Land of Oz, it is impossible to ---.
questions.explanation: Kiki states 'It is impossible to kill anyone in the Land of Oz' - this is a characteristic of the fairy land.

questions.question: A sparrow witnessed Kiki ---.

options.B: transforming into a magpie, stealing gold, and transforming back

questions.explanation: The sparrow says 'I saw you look in the window at the gold, and then make yourself into a magpie and rob the poor man, and then... make the bird into your former shape.'

questions.question: When the sparrow warned Kiki he would be sorry for being wicked, Kiki responded by saying ---.

options.B: he didn't care and was glad to be wicked
options.D: he thanked the sparrow for the warning

questions.explanation: Kiki says 'I don't care... I didn't know I was being wicked... but if I was, I'm glad of it. I hate good people. I've always wanted to be wicked.'

questions.question: Kiki and Ruggedo plan to base their operations in ---.

options.B: the thick forests of the Gillikin Country

questions.explanation: Ruggedo says 'We'll fly to Oz as birds and settle in one of the thick forests in the Gillikin Country.'

questions.question: Ruggedo promises Kiki that if they conquer Oz, ---.

options.A: Kiki will be the ruler of all Oz while Ruggedo becomes Prime Minister
options.B: they will split the kingdom in half
options.C: Kiki will get all the jewels
options.D: Kiki can return to Mount Munch as a hero

questions.explanation: Ruggedo says 'I'll agree to make you the ruler of all Oz, and I will be your Prime Minister and see that all your orders are obeyed.'

questions.question: To keep the paper with the magic word safe, Kiki ---.

options.B: hid it in his father's room
options.D: placed it in a tin box in a neglected part of the garden, covered with stones

questions.explanation: To make safety doubly sure 'he placed the paper in a tin box in a neglected part of the garden and covered the box with small stones.'

questions.question: When Kiki and Ruggedo meet the beasts in Gugu Forest, they call themselves ---.
questions.explanation: Ruggedo tells the forest beasts 'We are two Li-Mon-Eags... Our home is in Sky Island.'

questions.question: In L. Frank Baum's foreword, he suggests that real world events have become so marvelous that they rival his fantasy stories. What does this imply about the relationship between fantasy and reality?

options.A: Fantasy is always better than reality
options.B: Real world events can be as remarkable as the most imaginative fiction
options.C: Fantasy and reality should never mix
options.D: Reality is boring compared to fantasy

questions.explanation: Baum writes 'in the events which have taken place in the last few years in our great outside world, we may find incidents so marvelous and inspiring that I cannot hope to equal them with stories of the Land of Oz.'

questions.question: The relationship between Kiki and Ruggedo illustrates what moral lesson?

options.A: Crime always pays in the end
options.C: Two villains working together are stronger
options.D: Evil alliances are inherently unstable because wicked people cannot trust each other

questions.explanation: Both plan to betray the other, and the narrator states 'This is always the way with wicked people. They cannot be trusted even by one another.'

questions.question: What does Kiki's transformation from unhappy to content after leaving home suggest about his original problems?

options.A: He didn't really change at all
options.D: His unhappiness came from external restrictions, not internal character flaws

questions.explanation: Once free to explore the world, 'the young man was no longer unhappy, and so he was no longer cross and disagreeable' - his bad temper was caused by being trapped.

questions.question: What does Ruggedo's description of being 'a pretty good king - to myself' reveal about his character?

options.A: He was selfish and ruled only for his own benefit, not his people's
options.B: He was modest about his accomplishments
options.D: He was a fair and just king

questions.explanation: The phrase 'a pretty good king - to myself' reveals his self-serving nature - he ruled for his own benefit rather than his subjects'.

questions.question: Why does Baum playfully warn readers about pronouncing the magic word correctly?

options.B: To create narrative immersion and make readers feel the magic could be real

questions.explanation: Baum's warning 'to be careful not to pronounce Pyrzqxgl the proper way' is a storytelling device that makes readers feel they're sharing in a real magical secret.

questions.question: The loophole in Glinda's Book of Records (not recording animal actions) suggests what about magical surveillance systems?

options.A: Magic is always perfect and complete
options.B: Even powerful magical systems have limitations and can be circumvented
options.C: Animals are more important than people
options.D: Glinda is careless about her magic

questions.explanation: The fact that the Book only records human actions shows that even sophisticated magical systems have blind spots that clever villains can exploit.

questions.question: The contrast between Oz (no money) and other countries (money required) suggests what about Oz as a society?

options.A: Other countries are better places to live
options.B: Oz represents an ideal society without economic inequality, where needs are freely met

questions.explanation: In Oz 'everyone is allowed to take what he wishes without price' - contrasting with Kiki's experience elsewhere where he needed money, suggesting Oz as a utopian society.

questions.question: The condition that transformations only work on things that can talk represents what theme?

options.A: The power of language and speech as essential to identity and agency

questions.explanation: The requirement that transformed beings must be able to speak to transform back emphasizes that language/voice is essential to agency and identity.

questions.question: What does Bini Aru's obedience to Ozma's magic ban, despite never meeting her, suggest about legitimate authority?

options.D: Legitimate authority can be respected voluntarily when people recognize it as just

questions.explanation: Bini Aru 'had never seen Ozma, but he knew she was his ruler and must be obeyed' - showing voluntary respect for legitimate, recognized authority.

questions.question: The villain's plan to swap humans and animals comments on social hierarchies by suggesting that ---.

options.B: categories like 'civilized' vs 'beast' are arbitrary and could be reversed
options.C: only magic matters in determining status
options.D: animals are inherently better than people

questions.explanation: The plan to make 'beasts into men and women' and 'people of Oz into beasts' suggests the distinction between them is not natural but a matter of circumstance.

questions.question: Ruggedo's fear of eggs serves what narrative purpose?

options.B: It establishes his vulnerability and foreshadows how he might eventually be defeated

questions.explanation: The specific weakness to eggs (which previously helped defeat him) provides both humor and a potential solution to the threat he poses.

questions.question: The phrase 'it's the fashion to kick kings nowadays' reflects what about when Baum wrote this?

options.A: It references the decline of monarchies in the early 20th century, particularly around World War I
options.B: It's pure fantasy with no historical connection

questions.explanation: Written in 1919, this references the fall of monarchies (German, Austrian, Russian empires) during and after World War I.

questions.question: Why does Kiki memorize the magic word rather than just keeping the paper?

options.C: A bird cannot carry paper, so he must memorize it to transform back

questions.explanation: Kiki realizes 'a bird would have no way to carry a paper with it, and Kiki would be unable to resume his proper shape if he forgot the word.'

questions.question: The sparrow's role in the story represents ---.

options.C: a moral conscience warning against wickedness, and a witness to wrongdoing
options.D: just a random bird with no significance

questions.explanation: The sparrow witnesses Kiki's crime and warns 'You'll be sorry for this' - representing a moral voice that the villains dismiss.

questions.question: What irony exists in Kiki saying he 'always wanted to be wicked but didn't know how'?

options.D: It suggests wickedness must be learned, contradicting the idea that it's innate

questions.explanation: Kiki's statement implies wickedness is a skill to be acquired, ironically suggesting his current evil acts are a kind of education in wrongdoing.

questions.question: Ruggedo's failed search for 'magic tools' reveals what about his understanding of magic?

options.A: He expects magic to require physical implements, showing he doesn't understand Kiki's word-based power
options.B: Tools are unnecessary for any magic
options.D: He found the tools but pretended not to

questions.explanation: Ruggedo 'searched everywhere for the magic tool' because his own magic 'had to have certain tools' - he can't conceive of magic as simply speaking a word.

questions.question: The fact that animals can talk in Oz contributes to the transformation rules by ---.

options.A: enabling transformations into any creature while maintaining the ability to speak and change back
options.C: only allowing certain animals to be transformed

questions.explanation: Because 'all beasts and birds can talk in the Land of Oz,' one can safely transform into any creature and still speak the word to return.

questions.question: The title 'Royal Historian of Oz' that Baum uses suggests what about his relationship to his fictional world?

options.C: It positions him not as creator but as chronicler, enhancing the illusion that Oz is real

questions.explanation: By calling himself 'Royal Historian of Oz,' Baum plays the role of someone recording real events, making the fantasy feel more authentic.

questions.question: Why does Ruggedo agree to Kiki's condition of not knowing the magic word?

options.C: He believes he can spy on Kiki and learn the secret anyway
options.D: He gave up trying to learn it

questions.explanation: Ruggedo agrees because 'he decided that he could, by careful watching and listening, surprise the boy's secret' - he plans to learn it through espionage.

questions.question: Mount Munch's isolation has thematic significance because it represents how ---.

options.A: isolation can breed discontent (Kiki's unhappiness) but also preserve secrets (the magic word)
options.B: mountains are important geographic features in Oz
options.C: it simply protects the Hyups from outsiders
options.D: it's just geography with no deeper meaning

questions.explanation: The isolation makes Kiki unhappy but also allows Bini Aru to keep his magical secret hidden - showing isolation's dual nature as both prison and protection.
